Evaluating definite integrals

When you evaluate a definite integral the result will usually be a number. To see how to evaluate a definite integral consider the following Example.

Example

Find the definite integral of \(x^2\) from \(1\) to \(4\); that is, find \({\displaystyle \int_1^4 x^2 \,\mathrm{d}x}\)

Solution

\({\displaystyle \int{x^2} \,\mathrm{d}x} = \dfrac{x^3}{3}+c\). Thus according to our definition

\({\displaystyle \int_1^4x^2 \,\mathrm{d}x} = F(4)-F(1) = \dfrac{4^3}{3}-\dfrac{1^3}{3} = 21\)

Writing \(F(b)-F(a)\) each time we calculate a definite integral becomes laborious so we replace this difference by the shorthand notation  \(\left[\phantom{\dfrac{1}{1}}\!\!\!F(x)\right]_a^b\).

Thus \(\left[\phantom{\dfrac{1}{1}}\!\!\!F(x)\right]_a^b\equiv F(b)-F(a)\) Thus, from now on, we shall write \({\displaystyle\int_a^bf(x) \,\mathrm{d}x}=\left[\phantom{\dfrac{1}{1}}\!\!F(x)\right]_a^b\) so that, for example \({\displaystyle \int_1^4x^2 \,\mathrm{d}x} = \left[\dfrac{x^3}{3}\right]_1^4=\dfrac{4^3}{3}-\dfrac{1^3}{3}=21\)

Example

Find the definite integral of \(\cos x\) from \(0\) to \(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\); that is, find \({\displaystyle \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\cos(x) \,\mathrm{d}x}\)

Solution

\({\displaystyle \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\cos(x) \,\mathrm{d}x} = \left[\phantom{\dfrac{1}{1}}\!\!\!\sin(x)\right]_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} = \sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right)-\sin(0) = 1\).

Always remember, that if you use a calculator to evaluate any trigonometric functions, you must work in radian mode.
